quotes.topic_title: Invention takes little time, long execution
quotes.text: People think invention takes all this time, but you only need two hours once a month.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Reframes invention as a small, scheduled time investment rather than a constant grind, making it actionable for busy practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: Invention takes little time, long execution
quotes.text: The thing is, once you have one good idea, it often takes years to express that.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Highlights the mental model that ideation is brief but execution and iteration are the real long-term work.

quotes.topic_title: Invention takes little time, long execution
quotes.text: Jeff and Amazon had ideas like, "Let's have Prime shipping." Prime is still getting better and still being worked on. It's a 20 some year old idea.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Uses Prime as a concrete example that enduring products are multi-decade execution efforts, not one-time inventions.

quotes.topic_title: Invention takes little time, long execution
quotes.text: The point here is you don't need very many good ideas to be seen as tremendously inventive.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Offers a practical strategy: focus on a few high-leverage ideas and commit to long execution to build an inventive reputation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Ethan is a former vice president at Amazon, executive coach, and course creator focused on helping leaders grow into executives.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Establishes Ethan’s practitioner credibility and the episode’s practical focus on leveling up into executive roles.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: He led global teams of over 800, helped draft one of Amazon's 14 core leadership principles, holds over 70 patents, and currently spends his time executive coaching and running courses to help people advance in their career, build leadership skills, and succeed in senior roles.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete data points (team size, patents, leadership principles) that signal the depth of leadership and career-growth lessons to come.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Ethan shares an amazing story of when he failed on an important project for Jeff Bezos and what he learned from that experience.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a failure-based learning story—often the most transferable source of leadership and career insight.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We spent some time on something called The Magic Loop, which is a very simple idea that I guarantee will help you get promoted and advance in your career.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a named framework (“The Magic Loop”) positioned as a repeatable method for promotion and career advancement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best way to level up your career is to surround yourself with extraordinary peers.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: A clear career-growth heuristic emphasizing peer quality as a primary lever for advancement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When you have a trusted group of peers, you can discuss challenges you're having, get career advice, and just gut check how you're thinking about your work, your career, and your life.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: Practical description of how peer groups function as an ongoing feedback and decision-support system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: 93% of members a sidebar helped them achieve a significant positive change in their career.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: A concrete outcome metric that quantifies the claimed impact of the program.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Why spend a decade finding your people when you can meet them at Sidebar today?
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing that challenges the assumption that building a strong network must take many years.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It all starts with Sprig's precise targeting, which allows you to trigger in-app studies based on users' characteristics and actions taken in product.
quotes.speaker: Speaker name
quotes.context: A methodological starting point for product research: target feedback collection based on user segments and behaviors.

quotes.topic_title: The Magic Loop overview and five steps
quotes.text: So The Magic Loop is how to grow your career in almost any circumstance, even with a somewhat difficult manager.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Frames the methodology as broadly applicable, including when your manager isn’t ideal—making it a practical career-growth tool.

quotes.topic_title: The Magic Loop overview and five steps
quotes.text: Then step two is ask your boss how you can help. Speaking as a manager, and I've talked to hundreds of managers, very few people go and ask their manager, "What can I do to help you? What do you need?" And so just asking sets you apart, and it begins to build a relationship that we're on the same team, that I'm here as a part of your organization to make you successful, not just myself.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, differentiating behavior that builds trust and partnership with leadership.

quotes.topic_title: The Magic Loop overview and five steps
quotes.text: Once you've done that though, and maybe you do that a couple times, the fourth step is where the magic comes in. You go back to your manager and say, "Hey, I'm really enjoying working with you. I'm wondering is there some way I could help you that would also help me reach my goal?"
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Captures the key “trade value” move: aligning your manager’s needs with your own growth goals.

quotes.topic_title: The Magic Loop overview and five steps
quotes.text: And the reason this works is managers help those who help them. It's just human nature. We all do that.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Explains the underlying mechanism of the loop in a memorable, portable principle.

quotes.topic_title: The Magic Loop overview and five steps
quotes.text: And what I say about that is what your manager should do and $4 will get you a cup of coffee at Starbucks.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A sharp reframing that pushes practitioners to focus on what they can control rather than what “should” happen.

quotes.topic_title: Magic Loop proof, levels, and advanced mode
quotes.text: In the newsletter we did together, I wrote about how over time, you go from asking your manager, "How can I help?" To suggesting to your manager, "These are some things I see that seem like they need to be done. Would you like me to do them?" To just seeing what needs to be done and sort of keeping your leader in the loop and saying, "Hey, I noticed that we have this problem. I fixed it. I noticed we have this opportunity. I've started program against it." I think at the executive level, it's much more you being proactive and just keeping your leader in the loop.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A clear progression model for how “helpfulness” evolves into proactive leadership as you get more senior.

quotes.topic_title: Magic Loop proof, levels, and advanced mode
quotes.text: Yeah, well, it's all a matter of rapport and trust. A huge part of career success is how much trust you have, mutual respect with your leadership.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Highlights trust as the gating factor for when you can safely move into “advanced mode” autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Magic Loop proof, levels, and advanced mode
quotes.text: First, I mentioned how rare it is for managers to be offered help.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lever: simply offering help is uncommon enough to differentiate you and change the relationship dynamic.

quotes.topic_title: Magic Loop proof, levels, and advanced mode
quotes.text: Step one, make sure you're doing your current job well. The way I explain this is when you go to your manager and ask, "What could I do to help?" You don't want their answer, even if they don't say it quite so bluntly to be, "Do your F-ing job." You need to be doing that already. So be doing a good job.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A practical prerequisite that prevents the “help” loop from backfiring: competence first, then extra scope.

quotes.topic_title: Magic Loop proof, levels, and advanced mode
quotes.text: He went from a mid-level engineer to an executive with a team of 800 people.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A concrete outcome example that demonstrates the potential career trajectory associated with consistently applying the process.

quotes.topic_title: Getting unstuck at senior manager to director
quotes.text: But the other thing that causes people to get stuck is the difference between a senior manager and a director is how you lead and the work you're doing. And you can get as far as senior manager by being really strong in your function and being really good at getting things done. As a director, and as a VP beyond that, it becomes much more about influence, coordination with others, and letting go of being in all the details yourself. And so senior managers really have to change some behavior.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Clarifies the core skill shift required to move from senior manager to director: from execution and functional strength to influence and strategic leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Getting unstuck at senior manager to director
quotes.text: I often reference the book by Marshall Goldsmith, What Got You Here Won't Get You There. Not only because it's a great book classically on this problem, but because the title tells the story. All the great traits that got you to this one level won't get you to the next level where you're more expected to be thinking in strategic terms, thinking longer term.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why promotions stall: the next level demands different behaviors, especially longer-term strategic thinking.

quotes.topic_title: Getting unstuck at senior manager to director
quotes.text: And so promotions at this level, I often teach have two components. The first component is can I eat and do that job? Am I qualified? Do I have the skills? But the second piece is, do we have such a job that needs that?
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Provides a practical two-part framework for senior promotions: capability plus organizational need/timing.

quotes.topic_title: Getting unstuck at senior manager to director
quotes.text: And what is in your control is to start practicing those next level skills. Start working with your leadership on, where can I take on a strategic project? How can I become more of an inventor? I teach some about how to sort of systematically be inventive. It's not pure magic. Edison said it's 1% inspiration and 99% perspiration. You can learn the 99%, and the 1% isn't as hard then. So you start showing those next level traits. And as I describe it most succinctly, how do you make yourself the person who will be chosen out of the eight?
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what to do despite limited openings: deliberately practice next-level skills, seek strategic scope, and build “obvious pick” signal.

quotes.topic_title: Getting unstuck at senior manager to director
quotes.text: I experienced this at Amazon, where over a nine-year period I went from managing six people to 800. And so I went from a senior manager all the way to a vice president, and I described I was, in some sense just riding the elevator. The elevator was going up, and as long as I managed to stay on it, I was going to arrive at vice president.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how rapid org growth can mask promotion bottlenecks—and why today’s leaner environment changes the game.

quotes.topic_title: Systematic inventiveness and idea generation practice
quotes.text: And I figured out how to become systematically inventive. So I now hold over 70 patents as one benchmark of inventiveness, and they were all created during my 15 years at Amazon.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A concrete data point that frames inventiveness as a learnable, measurable practice over time.

quotes.topic_title: Systematic inventiveness and idea generation practice
quotes.text: And to invent systematically, first you do need to be somewhat of an expert in whatever area you want to invent.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A simple prerequisite that turns “innovation” from vague aspiration into a skill grounded in domain mastery.

quotes.topic_title: Systematic inventiveness and idea generation practice
quotes.text: But then the second thing people don't do is they don't spend dedicated time actually thinking. They feel like, "Invention is just going to come to me." When I want to invent, I get away from all my devices. I go in a room with the problem I have, and I force myself to actually concentrate on what do I know and how can I invent? And the most straightforward way to invent is not to somehow come up with something completely new, but instead to put together two things that exist.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A repeatable method: schedule distraction-free thinking time and generate ideas by combining existing concepts.

quotes.topic_title: Systematic inventiveness and idea generation practice
quotes.text: So that's part of the process, is put in dedicated time. The interesting thing I would say is you don't need that much time. Two hours is great, but you only need two hours once a month. People think invention takes all this time. The thing is once you have one good idea, it often takes years to express that.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A counterintuitive cadence that makes invention feel accessible: infrequent focused sessions can fuel years of execution.

quotes.topic_title: Systematic inventiveness and idea generation practice
quotes.text: So the point here is you don't need very many good ideas to be seen as tremendously inventive.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A reframing that prioritizes quality and follow-through over constant ideation volume.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing: enthusiasm, presence, and impact
quotes.text: There's a lot of evidence that suggests that the number one and two factors in any interview are appearance and enthusiasm.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Highlights a high-leverage, evidence-backed focus area for interview performance beyond just answering questions well.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing: enthusiasm, presence, and impact
quotes.text: I look at every interview of whether or not I really want this job, I might've decided I don't want the job. I still want the offer.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A contrarian mindset shift: treat interviews as a performance to earn optionality, even if you're unsure about the role.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing: enthusiasm, presence, and impact
quotes.text: Beyond those cosmetics, the biggest thing I see particularly at higher levels is people talk about what they have done but not why it mattered. They don't talk about the impact.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic for leveling up interview answers from task lists to business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing: enthusiasm, presence, and impact
quotes.text: See, a leader is not hiring someone to just do work. They're hiring someone because they have a problem or a need.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Reframes interviewing as problem-solving for the hiring manager, guiding candidates to tailor stories to needs.

quotes.topic_title: Interviewing: enthusiasm, presence, and impact
quotes.text: I often tell people the best way to prep for an interview might be a good night's sleep and a pot of coffee, that being fully engaged and energetic is a huge lever.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: Actionable preparation advice emphasizing energy and presence as a major differentiator, especially on Zoom.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Telling the story of your product is hard, and customers want you to show them your product, not just talk about it or gate it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable positioning advice: prioritize showing the product via demos over relying on marketing copy or gated experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Quantum Metric, the leading digital analytics platform created an interactive product tour library to drive more prospects.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of a repeatable tactic: build a library of interactive tours to increase top-of-funnel interest.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Arcade, they achieved a 2x higher conversion rate for demos and saw five times more engagement than videos.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific performance benchmark comparing interactive demos vs. video engagement and conversion.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: On top of that, they built the demo 10 times faster than before.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Operational efficiency data point suggesting interactive demos can reduce production time dramatically.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With browser-based recording, Arcade is the no-code solution for building personalized demos at scale.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Scalable methodology: use no-code, browser-based recording to create personalized demos without engineering effort.

quotes.topic_title: Failure corner: Appstore launch breaks for Bezos
quotes.text: So the first thing I did was I owned it. I said, "Yes, it's not working. It's my fault. I will deal with it." I took ownership.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A clear model for crisis leadership: explicitly own the failure to reduce ambiguity and rebuild trust.

quotes.topic_title: Failure corner: Appstore launch breaks for Bezos
quotes.text: And the second thing I did was start updating him very proactively and saying, "Here's where we are." 8:00 AM, "This is exactly where we are. This is what we're going to do and the next hour, and this is when you'll get your next update. I will update you again at 9:00 AM, so here's our plan."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A practical communication cadence (time-boxed updates + next plan + next check-in) for managing escalations.

quotes.topic_title: Failure corner: Appstore launch breaks for Bezos
quotes.text: So I was buying life one hour at a time.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for handling high-pressure incidents: earn continued autonomy through short, reliable intervals.

quotes.topic_title: Failure corner: Appstore launch breaks for Bezos
quotes.text: They had made some fundamental mistakes in our database usage and they said, "It's too complicated to fix this. We're just going to give you 500 AWS machines so that your crappy design will run anyway. That's the immediate fix."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A concrete example of prioritizing an immediate stabilizing workaround over an elegant fix during an outage.

quotes.topic_title: Failure corner: Appstore launch breaks for Bezos
quotes.text: But when I had that thought, I realized if I can't face the CEO, I'd better pack my desk. That's the end.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A counterintuitive career principle: avoiding hard conversations is a bigger risk than attending them.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding trust: facing Bezos after the incident
quotes.text: But when I had that thought, I realized if I can't face the CEO, I'd better pack my desk. That's the end.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A blunt career litmus test: if you can’t face hard accountability conversations, it’s a sign you can’t stay in the role.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding trust: facing Bezos after the incident
quotes.text: So I sat down right next to his chair and I thought, "I don't know, let's find out."
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A practical tactic for rebuilding trust: choose proximity and direct engagement instead of avoidance.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding trust: facing Bezos after the incident
quotes.text: Angry emails are easy. Sitting three feet from someone and being angry with them face-to-face is hard.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation about conflict: written “flaming” is low-cost, but real relationship repair happens in person.

quotes.topic_title: Rebuilding trust: facing Bezos after the incident
quotes.text: And when faced with, I can either start ranting at this person who reports to me, or I can say something nice, he chose to say something nice, and that rebuilt our relationship.
quotes.speaker: Ethan Evans
quotes.context: A simple decision framework for leaders: choose constructive humanity over venting to accelerate trust repair.
